content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Some building materials contain small capsules filled with paraffin wax to improve the insulating properties of the materials. The melting and freezing of paraffin inside the capsules in the material helps to regulate temperature. Paraffin wax begins to melt at <math alttext="37 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. A. While the wax is melting, is the net flow of thermal energy from the wax to the surroundings or from the surroundings to the wax? Justify your answer.

You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Some building materials contain small capsules filled with paraffin wax to improve the insulating properties of the materials. The melting and freezing of paraffin inside the capsules in the material helps to regulate temperature. Paraffin wax begins to melt at <math alttext="37 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. A. While the wax is melting, is the net flow of thermal energy from the wax to the surroundings or from the surroundings to the wax? Justify your answer.

B. Calculate the amount of thermal energy, in <math alttext="kilojoules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that is required to melt <math alttext="15.2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> grams of solid paraffin wax when the temperature of the surroundings is above the melting point of paraffin. (The molar mass of paraffin is <math alttext="282.62 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>282.62</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and its molar heat of fusion is <math alttext="48.78 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>48.78</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.)
C. When paraffin wax melts, its density decreases. Provide a particle-level explanation of this observation.
